'Quadrupedalism' is a form of terrestrial locomotion in animals using four limbs
or legs. An animal or machine that usually moves in a 'quadrupedal' manner is
known as a 'quadruped', meaning "four feet" (from the Latin quad for "four" and
ped for "foot"). The majority of quadrupeds are vertebrate animals, including
mammals such as cattle, dogs and cats, and reptiles, like lizards.

Birds, humans, insects, crustaceans, and snakes are not quadrupeds. However,
there are some exceptions. For example, among the insects, the praying mantis is
a quadruped. A few birds may use quadrupedal movement in some circumstances, for
example the shoebill will sometimes use its wings to right itself after lunging
at prey. http://scienceblogs.com/tetrapodzoology/2008/12/balaeniceps_rex.ph-
p#more
